awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploring Neuromorphic and Spintronic Behaviors in Ternary Transition Metal Dichalcogenide Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: Improving computational technology requires packing increasingly large numbers of transistors into smaller volumes. New approaches are needed as the achievable transistor density is reaching fundamental limits and the energy requirements for computing continue to grow. Next-generation technologies must therefore offer enhanced performance with reduced energy consumption. This project focuses on addressing the challenge of sustainable computing by developing materials capable of neuromorphic and spintronic computing behaviors. Neuromorphic computation mimics the brain by networking solid-state analogues of the neuron, which in turn provides hardware learning capabilities with low energy costs. Spintronics is a radically different field where computing occurs by shifting electron spin rather than charge, yielding speed boosts and improved efficiency over charge-based technology. This research team seeks to develop a material capable of combining these approaches by optimized alloying of transitional metal dichalcogenides, a class of atomically-thin materials, to create a new spintronic material that could mimic the biological neuron. The alloys investigated in the project could serve as the foundation of a neuromorphic-spintronic network that would fundamentally transform computing by combining the benefits of each technology. The research effort includes graduate, undergraduate and high school researchers in these studies and will promote interdisciplinary materials research while mentoring students at the Mason Innovation eXchange.

Technical Description: 2D transition metal dichalcogenides offer versatile electronic and structural properties based upon the choice of transition metal and chalcogen atoms, making them attractive for next-generation computation technologies. New behaviors can be engineered into these materials by developing ternary alloys, which in turn can enable unconventional device concepts. This project combines the intrinsic versatility of transition metal dichalcogenides with alloy engineering to address the challenge of sustainable computing technology by creating a material that can support both spintronic and neuromorphic behaviors. The primary objectives of this research are: 1) explore the phase diagram of a ternary transition metal dichalcogenide alloy to identify the composition optimal for achieving on-demand structural phase transitions; 2) evaluate the optical and electronic properties of the alloys to understand the impact of chalcogen substitution on spintronic functionality; and 3) trigger structural phase transitions in the alloy using heat, strain, or charge, and confirm the spintronic properties survive multiple switching cycles. Demonstrating these essential behaviors aims to prove the hypothesis that ternary transition metal dichalcogenide alloys are suitable for the future development of a combined neuromorphic-spintronic network.

por.por_cntn:
Improving the energy efficiency and processing power of modern computers is critical for achieving a sustainable future. This project focused on developing new materials for a hybrid next-generation computing architecture that mixes neuromorphic computing with spintronics. Neuromorphic computation mimics the brain by networking solid-state analogues of the neuron, which in turn provides hardware learning capabilities with low energy costs. Spintronics is a radically different approach where computing occurs by moving electron spin rather than charge, yielding speed boosts and improved efficiency over charge-based technology. This research team sought to develop a material capable of combining these approaches by alloying of transitional metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), a class of atomically-thin materials.

The Intellectual Merit outcomes of this project include: 1) the successful synthesis of transition metal dichalcogenide alloys and 2) the demonstration of spin-valley phenomena. Using a chemical vapor transport synthesis technique, our collaboration created alloys of WSe2 and WTe2 which have different crystal structures. We characterized the fundamental optical and vibrational behaviors of these materials and created van der Waals heterostructures using exfoliated monolayer encapsulated in hexagonal boron nitride. We characterized the temperature-dependent optical properties of these materials using polarization-resolved photoluminescence. The spin and valley degrees of freedom are closely related in TMDs and so our measurements can probe the suitability of these alloys for spintronics / valleytronics. Our measurements of the spin-valley polarization indicate that these desirable properties remain even at relatively high alloy compositions (Figure 1). Most interestingly, spin-valley properties in alloys are superior to the parent compound WSe2 at elevated temperatures, suggesting that alloy disorder shields against thermal fluctuations and other depolarization mechanisms. Therefore, the WSe2-WTe2 alloys are indeed capable of performing spintronic and neuromorphic computing operations.

The primary Broader Impact outcomes of this proposal include the training of five undergraduate researchers which include two veterans and one woman. These students have gone on to successful careers in industry and a PhD program in neuroscience. Two graduate students have been trained during this project, one of whom has now graduated and has found employment in the quantum technology industry. The PI has also conducted events at his home institution focused on ‘jargon free’ research forums where students can present their interdisciplinary research. This relaxed format encourages the development of scientific communication skills and provides a non-intimidating introduction to materials science for freshmen and sophomore undergraduate students.
